repository.corpname: Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford

did.bioghist: The Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford holds a small amount of material related to education of local Jewish students in the public schools and in institutions of higher learning. The society has greater holdings related specifically to Jewish educations that are described below. Public school education at the elementary and secondary level is also included here. The Jewish Education collection consists of material related to the many schools of Jewish education that have existed in Greater Hartford. Most of the material relates to secondary level programs. The collection also contains material related to issues related to Jewish education both locally and nationally Midrasha was established in 1963 as a Conservative supplemental after-school program for high school students. In 1970 Midrasha expanded its programs to include students from both Reform and Orthodox congregations as well as young people from unaffiliated families. Later, eighth graders were included when it became apparent that Jewish teenagers needed a program to bridge the gap between their Bar/Bat Mitzvah in seventh grade and high school. Midrasha merged with Beit No'ar in 1995 to form Yachad. Yachad (Greater Hartford Jewish Community High School) was founded in 1995 as a successor to Midrasha and Bet No'ar. Yachad provides an enrichment after-school Jewish experience to students from all branches of Judaism. Unlike Midrasha, Yachad offers time-limited studies and concentrates on recreation as well as academics. The Yachad program offers activities in art, music, theater, travel, student government and mitzvah programs. Hebrew High School of New England (HHNE) was founded in 1996 to provide secondary Jewish Education to students in the Springfield, Massachusetts, Hartford and New Haven regions. Although primarily Modern Orthodox in orientation, HHNE is open to all Jewish students. The school offers a coed secular curriculum and single-sex programs for Judaic education. HHNE's academic standards are demanding and rigorous in all subjects. The school was formerly housed in the education building of the Agudas Achim Synagogue. The HHNE moved into the permanent Grinspoon-Konover Building on Bloomfield Avenue in West Hartford, opening on January 3rd, 2011.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Note: records related to the two day schools, Hebrew Academy (formerly Hartford Yeshiva) and Solomon Schechter are filed separately in their own collections. Small files related to Beit Sefer Tichon are found with the JHSGH subject files.

scopecontent.head: Photographs
scopecontent.p: Most of the photographs in this collection are of Midrasha graduations. There are also some older photographs of early Jewish Education programs.

Series VII: Talmud Torah; General Education

Talmud Torah material is related to various "religious" or "Hebrew" schools that existed in Hartford in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The early Talmud Torah's generally existed independently of any one synagogue. After the middle of the twentieth century, individual synagogues usually sponsored their own Hebrew schools. Today the type of religious education offered in these schools is usually called "Jewish Education."
The General Jewish Education collection consists of material documenting broad educational concerns rather than specific organizations.
